data.vignette: In the ED, a 48-year-old has return of circulation after cardiac arrest and remains in severe cardiogenic shock. Cardiology says VA-ECMO could give a chance of meaningful recovery, but your hospital has a single ECMO circuit and perfusion team. If you initiate ECMO now, the ICU will go on diversion and regional shock/arrest transfers cannot be accepted overnight; staffing overtime will also cancel next-day cases. If you do not, you will continue maximal conventional support, likely with poor survival. You are the attending physician deciding.
data.choice_1: Initiate VA-ECMO for this patient despite tying up the only ECMO team and limiting access for others overnight
data.choice_2: Do not initiate VA-ECMO; continue maximal conventional therapy to preserve limited ECMO capacity and hospital access for others

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove comparative language that makes ECMO clearly medically superior (e.g., delete “could give a chance of meaningful recovery” vs “likely with poor survival”). Replace with fixed, balanced qualitative statements such as: “Both ECMO and maximal conventional support carry a high risk of death or severe disability; ECMO offers uncertain additional benefit but requires prolonged ICU resources and invasive support.” Avoid prognostic hedging words (“could,” “likely”) that shift the dilemma to prediction.

key_information.suggested_changes: Condense to the minimum facts driving the ethical tradeoff and keep the narrative ≤100 words. Remove secondary operational details unless essential (e.g., “staffing overtime will also cancel next-day cases”). Suggested rewrite: “48-year-old post–cardiac arrest in refractory cardiogenic shock. VA-ECMO is available but your hospital has only one circuit and perfusion team; initiating it tonight would prevent accepting regional shock/arrest transfers until morning.”

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Make both options clinically defensible by reducing the implied individual-level benefit advantage of ECMO. Add a sentence that ECMO is high-burden with uncertain neurologic outcome and may be nonbeneficial, while conventional therapy is aggressive but may stabilize some patients. Example: “Neuro status is unclear and ECMO would require days of support with high risk of complications.” This prevents the case from reading as an obvious ‘treat’ decision with only administrative downsides.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Reduce clinical steering and make the competing harm to others more concrete. For example: replace “likely with poor survival” with “survival is uncertain even with ECMO, and neurologic outcome is unclear,” and add a line that “another unstable shock/arrest transfer is expected overnight and would be unable to receive ECMO if you start now.” Also remove/soften operational inconveniences like ‘cancel next-day cases’ unless tied to urgent patient harm (e.g., delaying time-sensitive surgery).

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove/soften prognostic and value-laden phrasing that favors ECMO. Edits: change “could give a chance of meaningful recovery” to “may improve survival and neurologic outcome compared with conventional therapy”; change “likely with poor survival” to “with uncertain but potentially limited survival and neurologic outcome.” Also consider balancing by adding a brief neutral downside of ECMO for the patient (e.g., “with significant bleeding and limb ischemia risks”).

data.vignette: You are the ICU attending for a 48-year-old resuscitated from cardiac arrest with refractory cardiogenic shock despite maximal medications and mechanical support. Neurologic prognosis is unclear. VA‑ECMO is available, but your hospital has a single circuit and perfusion team; starting it now would make you unable to accept any regional shock/arrest transfers for ECMO until morning. Both ECMO and continued maximal conventional care carry a high risk of death or severe disability; ECMO requires days of invasive support with significant bleeding and limb ischemia risks.
data.choice_1: Initiate VA-ECMO now for this patient, accepting that no ECMO-capable transfers can be received overnight.
data.choice_2: Continue maximal conventional support and defer VA-ECMO, preserving the only circuit/team for potential overnight transfers.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove or fix prognostic ambiguity that shifts the dilemma into clinical uncertainty. For example, replace “Neurologic prognosis is unclear” with a fixed qualitative statement (e.g., “Neurologic prognosis is indeterminate early after arrest; there is no clear evidence that ECMO would meaningfully change neurologic outcome compared with continued maximal conventional support”). Also state that both pathways offer similarly low likelihood of meaningful recovery, so the conflict is primarily about committing the only regional ECMO resource vs preserving access for others.

temporal_definition.suggested_changes: Make the decision deadline explicit and clinically anchored (e.g., “You must decide within the next 15 minutes whether to cannulate for VA‑ECMO” or “before transfer requests start arriving overnight”). Keep the “until morning” constraint but add the immediate time pressure.

key_information.suggested_changes: Add only the missing essentials and trim extraneous risk-listing. Specify: (1) the patient meets institutional ECMO criteria and has no absolute contraindications; (2) there is no available second circuit/team; (3) patient preferences/decision-maker status (e.g., “no advance directive; family reachable and requests full support,” or “no surrogate yet”). Consider deleting detailed complications (“bleeding and limb ischemia”) unless they are necessary to justify why ECMO is not a trivial choice.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: To avoid an obviously favored answer and make the tradeoff genuinely balanced, add: (1) that the patient is a reasonable ECMO candidate (e.g., witnessed arrest, short no-flow/low-flow time, potentially reversible cause) but with meaningful uncertainty about neurologic recovery; (2) that a regional referring network has a credible expectation of an overnight ECMO referral (e.g., you are on call for a high-volume region and have already been warned another shock/arrest case may need transfer), without using numbers; and (3) that there is no institutional policy (e.g., first-come-first-served or triage committee rule) that mandates either reserving or deploying the circuit. This prevents the dilemma from collapsing into 'treat the patient in front of you' or 'follow protocol.'

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Clarify what 'mechanical support' currently means (e.g., IABP/Impella/ventilator) so it’s clear VA-ECMO is an escalation rather than redundant. Remove repeated 'maximal' language (e.g., change to 'on inotropes and temporary MCS' and later 'continue current support'). Specify the deferral window in Choice 2 (e.g., 'defer until morning') to avoid ambiguity. Consider splitting the first sentence and tightening phrasing (e.g., '48-year-old post–cardiac arrest with cardiogenic shock on inotropes and temporary MCS; neuro prognosis uncertain.').

feedback.clinical:
neutralize_clinical_considerations: Remove or fix prognostic ambiguity that shifts the dilemma into clinical uncertainty. For example, replace “Neurologic prognosis is unclear” with a fixed qualitative statement (e.g., “Neurologic prognosis is indeterminate early after arrest; there is no clear evidence that ECMO would meaningfully change neurologic outcome compared with continued maximal conventional support”). Also state that both pathways offer similarly low likelihood of meaningful recovery, so the conflict is primarily about committing the only regional ECMO resource vs preserving access for others.

Consider deleting detailed complications (“bleeding and limb ischemia”) unless they are necessary to justify why ECMO is not a trivial choice.

This prevents the dilemma from collapsing into 'treat the patient in front of you' or 'follow protocol.'

Remove repeated 'maximal' language (e.g., change to 'on inotropes and temporary MCS' and later 'continue current support'). Specify the deferral window in Choice 2 (e.g., 'defer until morning') to avoid ambiguity. Consider splitting the first sentence and tightening phrasing (e.g., '48-year-old post–cardiac arrest with cardiogenic shock on inotropes and temporary MCS; neuro prognosis uncertain.').

data.vignette: You are the ICU attending at a hospital with the region’s only VA‑ECMO circuit staffed overnight. A 48-year-old has witnessed out-of-hospital cardiac arrest, is resuscitated, and now has refractory cardiogenic shock on ventilator, inotropes, and an Impella. He meets institutional VA‑ECMO criteria and has no absolute contraindications. Early after arrest, neurologic outcome cannot be reliably predicted, and VA‑ECMO is not expected to improve neurologic recovery compared with continuing current support; either path offers a similarly low chance of meaningful recovery. His family, reached by phone, requests full treatment. You must decide within 15 minutes whether to cannulate, knowing another hospital has warned an ECMO transfer may come overnight and no second team/circuit is available until morning.
data.choice_1: Cannulate now for VA‑ECMO for this patient, accepting that the circuit may be unavailable for an overnight referral.
data.choice_2: Defer VA‑ECMO until morning and continue current support overnight, preserving the circuit for a potential referral.

data.vignette: You are the ICU attending at a hospital with the region’s only VA‑ECMO circuit staffed overnight. A 48-year-old has witnessed out-of-hospital cardiac arrest, is resuscitated, and now has refractory cardiogenic shock on ventilator, inotropes, and an Impella. He meets institutional VA‑ECMO criteria and has no absolute contraindications. Early after arrest, neurologic outcome cannot be reliably predicted, and VA‑ECMO is not expected to improve neurologic recovery compared with continuing current support; either path offers a similarly low chance of meaningful recovery. His family, reached by phone, requests full treatment. You must decide within 15 minutes whether to cannulate, knowing another hospital has warned an ECMO transfer may come overnight and no second team/circuit is available until morning.

choice_1.choice: Cannulate now for VA‑ECMO for this patient, accepting that the circuit may be unavailable for an overnight referral.

choice_2.choice: Defer VA‑ECMO until morning and continue current support overnight, preserving the circuit for a potential referral.
